metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (eddy covariance system of A’rou Superstation, 2023)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the A’rou superstation eddy covariance system (EC) in the upperstream reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2023. The site (100.372° E, 38.856° N) was located in the Daban Village, near Qilian County in Qinghai Province. The elevation is 3033 m. The EC was installed at a height of 3.5 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500A) was 0.15 m.
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1-3 (high quality), class 4-6 (good), class 7-8 (poor, better than gap filling data), class9 (rejected). In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 10% of the 30 min raw record. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. 
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) and Che et al. (2019).

background: The alpine region is important in riverine and watershed ecosystems as a contributor of freshwater, providing and stimulating specific habitats for biodiversity. In parallel, recent climate change, human activities, and other perturbations may disturb hydrological processes and eco-functions, creating the need for next-generation observational and modeling approaches to advance a predictive understanding of such processes in the alpine region. Water resources in the alpine region are headwaters that need to be regulated to sustain downstream ecosystems. However, perturbations induced by nature/climate change and human activities in recent years have significantly reformed hydrological processes and eco-functions. Accurate estimation and prediction of hydrological processes and their key impact factors has since become crucial.

Unfortunately, the scarcity of observation data in the alpine region, due to the difficulties of access and technological barriers, has hindered alpine hydrological modeling and associated research yet motivated the development of next-generation ecosystem observation networks and experiments. In comparison with the observations, using remote sensing data combined with data assimilation could improve the prediction of hydrological processes. However, due to the complexities of the earth system, there exist various sources of uncertainties in remote sensing data (especially in the alpine region), which have to be validated and calibrated. In summary, to fill the knowledge gap and promote alpine region hydrology research, an integrated, distributed and multiscale observation dataset is essential and expected to provide accurate forcing data for hydrological modeling, validate remote sensing data, allow the evaluation of distributed models and ultimately improve a predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions. In alpine hydrology, in addition to consistent hydrometeorological data obtained from distributed meteorological stations, snow cover and frozen ground are two important indexes and driving forces that manipulate hydrological processes. The maximum snow water equivalent (SWE) before ablation determines the storage of snowmelt – a major source of freshwater in the alpine region, while freeze-thaw cycles (FTCs) and soil moisture within the active layer alter water infiltration and, consequently, surface runoff and groundwater. To promote alpine hydrology research, the International Network for Alpine Research Catchment Hydrology (INARCH) was launched in 2015 by the Global Energy and Water Exchanges (GEWEX) project of the World Climate Research Programme (WCRP), involving 18 catchments around the world. The INARCH has since connected individual observatories into an international network and data-share platform to lead frontier research on alpine region hydrometeorology and snow observation. Another community-based observation network, the Circumpolar Active Layer Monitoring (CALM) network, was initiated in the early 1990s to observe the response of the active layer and near-surface permafrost to climate change. The Heihe River Basin (HRB) is the second largest inland river basin in China and is known for its heterogeneous landscapes, diverse ecosystems, unique geographical characteristics and climate change over recent decades. As a major component of the ecohydrological processes in the arid/semi-arid HRB, the alpine hydrological processes, especially those related to snow cover and frozen ground in the upper reaches, have great impacts on runoff in the mountainous region, which then regulate agricultural development in the middle reaches and the ecosystems of the lower reaches.

In recent years, with climate warming, permafrost degradation has significantly affected runoff and the carbon cycle (Peng et al., 2016; Gao et al., 2018). Snow cover is widely distributed with unique characteristics in the study area. In the high-altitude mountainous region (elevation > 3800 m), influenced by the local microclimate and low temperature, snowfall could occur in any season. Temporary snow is the major snow cover type in the region at middle and low elevations because strong solar radiation and high air temperature lead to fast melting and sublimation of the snow. Drifting snow is also commonly observed in the region, which may lead to the redistribution of snowpack in high elevation regions (Essery et al., 1999; Li et al., 2014).

Blowing (drifting) snow is commonly observed in the Qilian mountain due to its high altitude and complex terrain. It is important to estimate the occurrence of blowing snow because it may cause redistributions of the snow cover and influence the sublimation of snow.

Soil heat conductivity is difficult to analyze because it is a function of soil density, soil moisture content (ice content in frozen ground), and soil temperature, which cannot be easily calculated using a simple formula. Therefore, site observations can be utilized to evaluate the parameterization of alpine hydrologic models.

This paper introduces the infrastructure of the integrated alpine hydrology observation network in the HRB and the complete datasets collected in recent years.

The associated open-access datasets include high-quality hydrometeorological data with specific respect to snow and frozen ground observations at the sub-basin and basin scales, which aims to address a variety of scientific questions including but not limited to: (1) how to provide accurate and effective forcing data for alpine hydrological models, (2) how to integrate observation, simulation and the acquired datasets for informative understanding, and (3) how perturbations (climate change and human activities) alter fundamental processes.

methods: Gap-free meteorological and hydrological data were monitored from an observation network connecting a group of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs). In addition, to capture snow accumulation and ablation processes, snow cover properties were collected from a snow observation superstation using state-of-the-art techniques and instruments. High-resolution soil physics datasets were also obtained to capture the freeze-thaw processes from a frozen ground observation superstation.

Considering the characteristics of the study site, an integrated, distributed and multiscale hydrometeorological – snow – frozen ground observation network has been established with seven automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) and two superstations. At the basin scale, the observation aims to collect data for investigating the meteorological driving forces and for validation of the alpine hydrological models. At the sub-basin scale, small-scale observations and measurements focus on data such as precipitation, soil temperature and moisture, which are used to develop and improve hydrologic models, as well as to validate remote sensing products at medium to coarse resolutions (Jin et al., 2014). At the two superstations for snow cover and frozen ground observations, remote sensing products can be further validated using fine-resolution data. In total, seven AMSs, as well as the frozen ground and snow superstations (also incorporating meteorological observations), were established in the study area during the intensive observation period (IOP: 2013 -2014) to obtain the spatially distributed meteorological variables. After the IOP, four typical AMSs were selected and retained for continuous observation, which is expected to provide long-term datasets. The observed meteorological variables include wind (speed and direction), air temperature, humidity, infrared temperature, air pressure, four-component radiation, and precipitation. Accumulation and depletion processes were measured automatically at the Yakou snow superstation. The observed components included snow depth, snow water equivalent (SWE, measured by GammaMONitor, GMON), albedo of the snow surface and blowing (drifting) snow flux (measured by FlowCapt). Soil temperature and moisture were measured within six layers at each AMS, while evapotranspiration (ET) was observed by eddy covariance (EC) at three AMSs located in permafrost, seasonally frozen ground and a transient zone to observe freeze-thaw (FT) processes. At the sub-basin scale, a wireless sensor network (WSN) with 40 nodes was established to capture seasonal changes in soil temperature and moisture. At the A’rou frozen ground superstation, soil temperature and moisture profiles were intensively measured in eighteen layers to a depth of 3.2 m (in a nested pattern with more layers in the topsoil) to obtain the soil hydrothermal features under freeze-thaw cycles (FTCs). In addition, thermal conductivity and hydraulic conductivity in the topsoil were also measured to observe the dynamic hydrothermal processes within.

Snow depth was measured by SR50A (Campbell, USA), which determines the distance between the sensor and the target by sending out ultrasonic pulses and listening for the returning echoes reflected from the target. Snow water equivalent (SWE) was measured by GMON (CS725 GammaMONitor, Campbell, USA) from 2014/1/1 to 2017/12/31 at a temporal resolution of 6 hr. FlowCapt (IAV, Switzerland) was used to measure the number of blowing snow grains at 3 heights (0-1 m, 1-2 m, and 2-3 m) every 10 mins.
dataset: The current study presents a suite of datasets consisting of long-term hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data for investigating watershed science and functions from an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) in China. Gap-free meteorological and hydrological data were monitored from an observation network connecting a group of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs). In addition, to capture snow accumulation and ablation processes, snow cover properties were collected from a snow observation superstation using state-of-the-art techniques and instruments. High-resolution soil physics datasets were also obtained to capture the freeze-thaw processes from a frozen ground observation superstation. The updated datasets were released to scientists with multidisciplinary backgrounds (i.e., cryosphere science, hydrology, and meteorology), and they are expected to serve as a testing platform to provide accurate forcing data and validate and evaluate remote sensing products and hydrological models for a broader community.

This paper introduces the infrastructure of the integrated alpine hydrology observation network in the HRB and the complete datasets collected in recent years. Composed of seven standard hydrometeorological stations, one snow superstation and one frozen ground superstation, the observation network serves as an integrated research platform aiming to provide prominent datasets (e.g., hydrometeorology, snow, and frozen ground) of the hydrometeorological processes in the upper reaches of the HRB, which is expected to support alpine region hydrological model development and simulations along with remote sensing observation.

A comprehensive snow dataset from the Yakou snow superstation has been updated since the summer of 2013. The observed snow variables included snow depth, snow water equivalent (SWE) and blowing (drifting) snow. Data obtained from 2014/1/1 to 2017/12/31 are summarized in Figure 4, with additional plots for precipitation, ET, soil temperature and moisture. The datasets are available from 2012/12/05 to 2017/12/31, with intermittent loss mostly due to power loss and sensor malfunctions at high altitudes.

In this paper, a suite of alpine hydrology datasets observed from an integrated, distributed and multiscale hydrometeorological – snow – frozen ground observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) is presented.

Definition.Question: What is an 'integrated, distributed and multiscale observation network' in the context of alpine hydrology research?
Definition.Answer: An 'integrated, distributed and multiscale observation network' refers to a system designed to collect data across various spatial scales and locations, incorporating a range of observation techniques and technologies to gather comprehensive hydrometeorological, snow, and frozen ground data. This network aims to address scientific questions related to alpine hydrological processes, validate remote sensing data, and improve the predictive understanding of these processes.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do challenges in data collection differ between high-altitude alpine regions and more accessible areas for hydrological research?
Comparison.Answer: High-altitude alpine regions present unique challenges such as harsh climate, complex topography, and limited access, which hinder consistent data collection and the development of remote sensing technologies. In contrast, more accessible areas may not face such extreme conditions, allowing for more stable and comprehensive data collection efforts.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges in data collection are suggested by the complex terrain and climate in alpine regions, and how do these challenges affect the completeness and consistency of data?
Interpretation.Answer: Several challenges like cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography inhibit complete and consistent data collection in alpine regions. These factors hinder the development of remote sensing technologies and alpine hydrological models due to difficulties in accessing data and technological barriers.

Interpretation.Question: How do the integration of remote sensing data and site observations help mitigate uncertainties in alpine hydrological modeling?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating remote sensing data with site observations helps improve the prediction of hydrological processes by providing validation and calibration. Despite complexities and uncertainties in remote sensing data, particularly in alpine regions, this approach can enhance the accuracy of hydrological models and validate remote sensing products.

Interpretation.Question: What are the implications of using an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network for understanding and modeling alpine hydrological processes?
Interpretation.Answer: An integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network provides essential data for understanding alpine hydrological processes by capturing consistent hydrometeorological data, snow cover, and frozen ground dynamics. This network helps validate and improve hydrological models, address scientific questions, and analyze perturbations' impacts on fundamental processes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying causes that create challenges in collecting complete and consistent data in alpine hydrological research?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Several formidable challenges, including the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography, inhibit complete and consistent data collection where/when needed, which hinders the development of remote sensing technologies and alpine hydrological models.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why has the development of next-generation ecosystem observation networks and experiments become necessary in the alpine region?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The scarcity of observation data in the alpine region, due to the difficulties of access and technological barriers, has hindered alpine hydrological modeling and associated research, motivating the development of next-generation ecosystem observation networks and experiments.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the scarcity of high-quality snow and frozen ground data needed for alpine hydrological model parameterization?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The availability of forcing data is limited, as only two weather stations operated by the Chinese Meteorological Administration functioned in the upper reaches of the HRB, and there is a lack of high-quality snow and frozen ground data for parameterization.

Causal Consequence.Question: How do technological barriers and harsh environmental conditions affect the completeness and consistency of data collected in alpine observation networks?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Technological barriers and harsh environmental conditions can severely impact the completeness and consistency of data collected in alpine observation networks. These challenges inhibit full data collection when needed, leading to intermittent data loss, which in turn hinders the development and parameterization of hydrological models and the validation of remote sensing technologies.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of integrating datasets from multiple observation methods, such as remote sensing and in-situ observations, for advancing alpine hydrological research?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating datasets from multiple observation methods, such as remote sensing and in-situ observations, can improve the prediction of hydrological processes by providing a more comprehensive understanding of the alpine ecosystem. This integration allows for validation and calibration of remote sensing data, addresses various scientific questions, and ultimately enhances the understanding of how perturbations alter fundamental processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the key objectives of establishing an integrated alpine hydrology observation network in the upper reaches of a river basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The key objectives include providing accurate and effective forcing data for alpine hydrological models, integrating observation and simulation for a comprehensive understanding, and assessing the impact of perturbations like climate change and human activities on fundamental hydrological processes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is data quality assessed and what specific procedures are followed to ensure the reliability of hydrometeorological observations in alpine environments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data quality is assessed through various procedures, including the evaluation of atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics. The data undergoes processing steps such as outlier removal, time lag correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and density correction. Quality assessment criteria involve tests for atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics. Additionally, data is screened to remove erroneous data from instrument errors, data around precipitation events, and data with high missing rates.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are employed to capture snow accumulation and ablation processes in the Heihe River Basin's alpine observation network?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To capture snow accumulation and ablation processes, a snow observation superstation using advanced techniques and instruments is utilized. Snow depth is measured by SR50A sensors through ultrasonic pulses, while snow water equivalent (SWE) is measured by GammaMONitor (GMON) at a 6-hour temporal resolution. Blowing snow is measured using FlowCapt at multiple heights to account for snow redistribution and sublimation. These methodologies help in collecting comprehensive data on snow cover properties.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in collecting and processing data from the eddy covariance method for observing evapotranspiration in alpine regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The eddy covariance method involves the use of instruments like the CSAT3 sonic anemometer and the Li7500A CO2/H2O analyzer, mounted at specific heights to capture high-frequency data. Raw data is collected at a 10 Hz frequency and processed using Eddypro software to produce 30-minute averaged datasets. The processing includes outlier removal, time lag correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response adjustment, and density correction. Data is then quality-assessed based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity, and filtered for errors and missing data.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the collection of detailed snow cover and frozen ground data in alpine regions?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements such as automatic meteorological stations (AMSs), state-of-the-art snow observation instruments at superstations, and devices like the CS725 GammaMONitor and FlowCapt have enabled detailed collection of snow cover and frozen ground data. These technologies help capture variables such as snow depth, snow water equivalent, and blowing snow flux, which are crucial for understanding alpine hydrological processes.

Expectation.Question: Why might the alpine region face challenges in maintaining consistent and complete data collection, despite advances in observation networks?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges such as the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography inhibit complete and consistent data collection where/when needed, which in turn hinders the development of remote sensing technologies and alpine hydrological models.

Expectation.Question: What are the potential reasons for the scarcity of observation data in alpine regions, and how does this impact hydrological modeling?
Expectation.Answer: The scarcity of observation data in alpine regions is due to difficulties of access and technological barriers, which hinders alpine hydrological modeling and associated research. This scarcity has motivated the development of next-generation ecosystem observation networks and experiments.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be difficulties in accurately estimating snow density in alpine regions, even with advanced observation methods?
Expectation.Answer: Accurate estimation of snow density is challenging due to the influence of strong wind, which affects the available data. Therefore, snow density data, which can be calculated using snow depth and snow water equivalent (SWE) data, are not readily available.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using Eddypro software for processing eddy covariance data in terms of accuracy and reliability?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of Eddypro software for processing eddy covariance data involves several key steps such as outlier removal, delay time correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density corrections. These steps are essential for ensuring data accuracy and reliability. Additionally, quality assessment of flux values is conducted, which further enhances the reliability of the processed data.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the primary challenges faced in collecting comprehensive hydrometeorological data in alpine regions, and how can they be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: The primary challenges include the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography, which inhibit complete and consistent data collection. These challenges hinder the development of remote sensing technologies and alpine hydrological models. To address these, integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation networks, such as automatic meteorological stations and superstations, have been established to capture detailed and gap-free data. These networks are crucial for improving data availability and quality.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential benefits of integrating remote sensing data with traditional observation methods in alpine hydrology research?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating remote sensing data with traditional observation methods can significantly improve the prediction of hydrological processes by providing comprehensive spatial coverage and capturing dynamic changes over time. Despite uncertainties in remote sensing data, validation and calibration with ground-based observations can enhance data reliability. This integration helps in providing accurate forcing data for hydrological modeling, validating remote sensing products, and improving the understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand how data collection in harsh alpine conditions can be consistently reliable.
Assertion.Answer: The field highlights that the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography present significant challenges to consistent data collection. However, to tackle these, an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network has been established, including automatic meteorological stations and superstations for snow and frozen ground observations. These stations utilize state-of-the-art techniques and instruments to capture the necessary data.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure how researchers can effectively validate remote sensing data in such a complex environment.
Assertion.Answer: In this domain, remote sensing data validation is achieved through comprehensive observation networks that collect high-quality ground-based data. For example, snow and frozen ground superstations provide fine-resolution data that can be used to validate remote sensing products, addressing uncertainties and improving predictive understanding of hydrological processes.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how snow cover and frozen ground observations are integrated into hydrological models.
Assertion.Answer: Snow cover and frozen ground observations are integrated into hydrological models by providing detailed datasets that capture snow accumulation, ablation processes, and freeze-thaw cycles. This data helps improve model parameterization, allowing for accurate simulation and prediction of alpine hydrological processes and their impact on watershed science and functions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an evaluation of integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation networks for alpine hydrology research, focusing on their effectiveness in addressing scientific questions related to hydrological processes.
Request/Directive.Answer: Integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation networks are effective tools for alpine hydrology research as they provide comprehensive datasets that address scientific questions related to hydrological processes. These networks consist of automatic meteorological stations, snow superstations, and frozen ground superstations that capture a range of variables such as wind, temperature, snow depth, and soil moisture. By providing gap-free and high-resolution data, these networks aid in the development and validation of hydrological models and remote sensing products, facilitating an improved understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the potential methodologies for improving the accuracy and coverage of datasets used for studying watershed science and functions in the upper reaches of river basins.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential methodologies for improving dataset accuracy and coverage in river basin studies include the integration of remote sensing data with ground-based observations, utilizing data assimilation techniques, and establishing more comprehensive observation networks. These approaches can help fill observation gaps, validate remote sensing data, and improve the parameterization of hydrological models. Additionally, employing advanced instruments and techniques such as high-resolution soil physics datasets and fine-resolution meteorological data can enhance the understanding of watershed science and functions.
